entry.title: Re: Dates and Roundings in Compensation
entry.content:
HI ..

Can anyone help me with below requirement.

 

a. If the “Hiring Date”  ≤ December 31, 2024, then “AB Pro-rata” = “AB Target”.

b. If instead the “Hiring Date” > December 31, 2024, then “Hiring Day” and “Hiring Month” are considered, applying the formula
“AB Pro-rata” = “AB Target” * (x/12) where:

  • x = (12 – “Hiring Month” + 1) if Hiring Day ≤ 15
  • x = (12 – “Hiring Month”) if Hiring Day > 15

    By way of example:
    • If the “Hiring Date”  = December 30, 2024, then “AB Pro-rata” = “AB Target”.
    • If the “Hiring Date”  = February 14, 2025, then “AB Pro-rata” = “AB Target” * (11/12), since “Hiring Month” = February = 2, Hiring Day = 14 (≤ 15), and therefore x = (12 – 2 + 1) = 11.
    • If the “Hiring Date”  = May 18, 2025, then “AB Pro-rata” = “AB Target” * (7/12), since “Hiring Month” = May = 5, Hiring Day = 18 (> 15), and therefore x = (12 – 5) = 7.

entry.title: Re: delivery block at credit management in Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Dear @test4,

In Public Cloud can block delivery processing due to Credit Management, but it’s done via SAP Credit Management (FSCM) statuses/checks credit block, not via the classic SD simple credit check logic. When the credit check fails, the system can prevent delivery creation and/or later steps like picking and PGI, depending on how you configure it

That’s expected credit check types A/B/C (simple checks) are no longer available in SAP Credit Management for sales document types you can only use type D (Automatic) or leave it blank (no check)

So in CBC:

  • Set Credit Limit Checks for Sales Document Types (102137) only D is supported
  • Set Credit Limit Checks for Delivery Types (101707) you control which delivery types are checked and which credit group they use it does not mean A/B/C are available

More details below from SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3367948

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3450345

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002900255

How to get a delivery block/credit block in Public Cloud

In CBC:

  1. Set Credit Limit Checks for Delivery Types (101707), assign the relevant delivery type to the credit group for:
    • Delivery (commonly credit group 02) and/or
    • Goods Issue / PGI (commonly credit group 03)
  2. Define Automatic Credit Control (101518), for your Credit Segment + Risk Class + Credit Group (02/03), activate the SAP Credit Management check and set the blocking behavior. This is what actually enforces blocking at delivery/PGI

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3674047

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002670121

Important Public Cloud behavior/limitation

If a delivery is credit blocked, the system can hard-stop Picking and PGI when exposure exceeds the limit and deliveries can’t be manually credit-released via Manage Documented Credit Decisions that app supports sales orders, not deliveries

More details below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003670434

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F5587')/S35

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003596276

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/credit-check-is-not-working-for-delivery/qaq-p/13628903

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.content:

Can you please refer to the following information?

Invoice with Variances

Make settings in the configuration activity "Automatic Account Determination" (100297).

Account Determination

[Generative AI content] You can configure the system to post variances to specific accounts by setting up account determination rules. This involves configuring the account determination for variances using the above-mentioned configuration activity. 
If automatic posting to a variance account is not feasible, you might need to manually adjust the postings after the invoice is posted. This involves creating a journal entry to transfer the price difference from the account specified in the PO item to the desired variance account.

entry.title: Re: Incorrect name of company in ZENGINKYO payment media...
entry.content:
Good day @hyik 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/8e71a76adeb84940b785936842cc7574.html?locale=en-US

The name of company you displayed in your screenshot is most likely pulled from your Central Business Configuration where Legal Entities was defined or Set Global Parameters for Company Code (SSCUI 100066). Even if you haven’t manually entered it elsewhere, the value was probably taken from the initial system setup.

Step 1: You can check what detail is configured in your system by going to Manage Your Solution App, then click Configure Your Solution. Use the search function to find Set Global Parameters for Company Code. Thereafter open th config activity, then review the Compan Name. That is what the system often displays in print forms or output.

Step 2: If you have Central Business Configuration active, then open the config environment, go to Define Legal Entities or Define Company Codes. Search for the Company Name, which syncs to S/4.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Credit Memo on Asset Triggers “Negative Acquisition Value” Error- Explanation requested
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I’d like to share an update regarding an issue I previously raised. When posting a credit memo on an asset in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the system triggers error messages about negative acquisition values—even for very small amounts (e.g., 1 euro).

 

Context:

  • The asset is still in the first year of its useful life. (5years)

  • The asset class is ZMAT.

Temporary Solution Applied: Following community advice, we enabled the “Negative values allowed” option temporarily in the asset master data. This allowed us to successfully post the credit memo.

My Question:

Could you please help me understand the business rationale behind this behavior and the implications of applying this workaround? I am aware that enabling “Negative values allowed” is generally recommended for Assets under Construction (AuC), but does the same recommendation apply to fixed assets as well? In other words, is this workaround considered a best practice by SAP, or should we explore alternative configurations to prevent potential issues in reporting, compliance, or asset management in the future?

 

Thank you in advance for your insights!

FIN Asset Accounting  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Asset Management  SAP ERP

entry.title: Re: Are C_CPE and C_HAMOD right for my Java + spring boot...
entry.content:
Your plan is definitely on the right track. With 11 years of experience in Java Spring Boot and strong PL/SQL skills, moving to SAP BTP and HANA Cloud is a natural and smart progression. SAP promotes a clean core approach, meaning custom logic is added as side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP rather than modifying the ABAP core in ERP.

Starting with the C_CPE certification is ideal because it formalizes your current cloud-native app, security, and API skills in the SAP ecosystem using CAP, OAuth/XSUAA, and SAP Build Code. Your PL/SQL skills also translate well to HANA SQLScript and data modeling, making HANA Cloud essential for analytics and AI-positive future scenarios. To enhance your skills, aim to become an SAP BTP Extension Developer with a focus on Java and CAP, while also gaining knowledge in HANA Cloud for data and AI, and eventually learning SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh for integrating real projects with S/4HANA.

entry.title: How to connect non-ABAP Products Built in On-Premises Environment to SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
We have built SAP HANA Cockpit, SAP IQ, and SAP SDI within our own Azure environment.
Is it possible to connect these products to SAP Cloud ALM and use features such as Health Monitoring?
If possible, please provide information on:

  • Connection method
  • Available features after connection



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to connect non-ABAP Products Built in On-Premises...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

Thank you for reaching out with your query. Your case has reached the SAP Cloud ALM team.

Yes, it is possible to connect SAP HANA Cockpit, SAP IQ, and SAP SDI within your Azure environment to SAP Cloud ALM. Non-ABAP/non-SAP system data can be pushed into SAP Cloud ALM for operations use cases via the SAP Cloud ALM APIs.

This allows you to integrate and monitor these products within SAP Cloud ALM, including leveraging Health Monitoring.

 

Connection Method:

To integrate your systems, you can use the relevant SAP Cloud ALM APIs for pushing data. Specifically, the Raw Metrics, Raw Logs, and Raw Traces APIs will allow you to send operational data to SAP Cloud ALM.

 

Available Features:

Once connected, you can utilize various SAP Cloud ALM features, such as Health Monitoring, to monitor and manage the performance of your systems. The specific metrics and logs you can collect will depend on the data you push into the system.

 

For detailed information on how to integrate and utilize these features, I recommend referring to the following documentation:

  • SAP Cloud ALM Raw Data Inbound Metrics API
  • Raw Data Inbound Metrics API Documentation

These resources will provide more specific guidelines on how to configure the connection and the features available.

 

Kind Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: How to Enhance Sales Order Item Processing in SAP: Tabstrip UI + Popup Quantity Editing
entry.content:
I've been looking at this for some time now, and I have a hard time figuring out what its purpose is:

  • "Effective use of classic SAP GUI dialog programming" would be one, if it wasn't so full of bad programming practices (misused Hungarian notation, badly formatted source with inconsistent use of white space, magic numbers, no encapsulation of logic, cryptically named subroutines, ...)
  • "Clean user-driven quantity update process" eludes me - I can't see the part where anything is being updated
  • "Practical design for logistics screens" is also a miss, for a variety of reasons (layout includes tons of white space, buttons are loosely positioned without logic and too small with cryptical labels, ...).

Overall, while the effort of publishing code samples is commendable, this here mainly works as a bad example... Let's just hope that no AI will ever use this as a basis to generate code.

entry.title: Re: how to create multiple work orders at once in fieldgl...
entry.content: Based on the current SAP Fieldglass functionalities, there is no built-in way to create multiple work orders in batch/bulk without using the 'Work Order Request Import' functionality, which typically involves a CSV upload. This is the standard method for batch creation. If you need an alternative that avoids the CSV upload, it would require developing a custom integration using SAP Fieldglass APIs. This approach demands technical expertise to program a solution that interacts directly with the system for bulk work order creation. For more information on SAP Fieldglass integrations and APIs, you can refer to the SAP Help Portal (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_FIELDGLASS/20120120120120120120120120120120/12345678.html)

entry.title: SAP Neo Retires – Integration Developers Must Know Before Migrating from Neo to CF
entry.content:
SAP has announced the end of maintenance for the SAP Cloud Integration Neo environment by December 31, 2028. This impacts customers running Cloud Integration on Neo and planning to move to the Cloud Foundry–based SAP Integration Suite.

Migrating integration flows from Neo to Cloud Foundry is not a simple export/import of iflows.
Both environments differ significantly in:

  • Infrastructure
  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & monitoring
  • Environment variables
  • APIs
  • Security materials
  • Transport & lifecycle management

This blog summarizes the key Neo vs. Cloud Foundry differences you must consider before starting your CPI migration.

1. Cloud Integration Availability: Neo vs. Cloud Foundry

Neo

  • CPI is available as a standalone product
  • Runs in SAP-managed data centers
  • Uses Neo cockpit & proprietary deployment mechanisms

Cloud Foundry

  • CPI is part of the SAP Integration Suite capability
  • Runs on hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Uses standard CF principles for scaling, service bindings, logging

📌Important: Some Neo features may not be available or behave differently in CF (refer to Note 2903776).

2. Adapter Deployment Differences

Neo

  • Custom adapters deployed using Eclipse plugin
  • Adapter artifacts managed in Neo cockpit

Cloud Foundry

  • Custom adapters are deployed as Integration Adapter artifacts
  • Managed via Cloud Integration Design & Monitor applications
  • Deployment uses CF-based lifecycle mechanisms

Impact:
If you have custom adapters built for Neo, they must be rebuilt or repackaged for Cloud Foundry. Here is the help document to create custom adapters Developing Customer Adapters

3. Logging Differences - Audit Logs & Access Logs

Neo

  • Audit logs retrieved via Neo Audit Log API
  • Access logs available under “Access Logs” section

Cloud Foundry

  • Audit logs available through SAP Audit Log Service
  • Access logs integrated with Application Logs
  • Monitoring done via Cloud Integration Monitor

Impact:
Integrations relying on Neo-specific APIs must be redesigned for CF logging services. Here is the help document related to Audit logging in CF environment Audit Logging in CF 

4. Environment Variables - Critical Migration Topic

We can use environment variables in integration flows to address technical details like the region,port..etc where Cloud Integration is deployed.

The following table provides the mapping of environment variables in Neo and Cloud Foundry.

 

Variable Name - NeoVariable Name -CFDescription

HC_APPLICATION

Example value: abcd01iflmap

TENANT_NAME

Example value: xyz001

Sub domain of worker application (associated with application identifier for worker node)

HC_APPLICATION_URL

Example value: abcd01iflmap.uvwxy.eu1.hana.ondemand.com

TENANT_NAME + IT_SYSTEM_ID + IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: xyz001.it-cpi001.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

URL of the worker application sub domain

HC_HOST

Example value: hana.ondemand.com

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Base URL of the SAP BTP region host where the application is deployed

HC_LOCAL_HTTP_PORT

Example value: 9001

PORT

Example value: 8080

HTTP port of the application bound to localhost

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_HOST

VCAP_SERVICES

Host of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_PORT

Example value: 20003

VCAP_SERVICES

Example value: 20003

Port of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_REGION

Example value: EU_1

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Region where the application is deployed

Here is the nice blog on how to call/get environment variable in CF Integration flows - identify-sap-cloud-integration-tenant-stage-at-runtime 

5. OData API Access Considerations

Neo

  • Uses Neo-based OAuth clients
  • API base URLs differ
  • Some OAuth grant types are Neo-specific

Cloud Foundry

  • Requires enabling API clients via XSUAA
  • Uses Integration Suite base URLs
  • Authentication flows must be updated

For example:
If you use CPI OData APIs for CI/CD, monitoring, or automation, the endpoints and tokens must be regenerated. Here is the help document gives more details on inbound communication setup - connection setup for inbound communication for api clients 

6. Transport Management & Lifecycle Changes

For the transport of integration content across different tenants, different options are available:

  • Manual export and import
  • Usage of CTS+
  • Usage of the cloud-based Transport Management

These options are identical independent of the environment (Cloud Foundry or Neo). However, setting up transport management using the cloud-based Transport Management service is different in both environments

7. Security Materials (Certificates, Keys, OAuth)

Neo

  • Keystore stored and managed directly inside Neo cockpit
  • OAuth clients created using Neo administration tools

Cloud Foundry

  • Uses Service Instances for trust stores
  • Certificates and keys must be re-imported
  • OAuth clients created via Integration Suite

Impact:
Rebuild all security configurations - especially if you use SFTP, AS2, OData, or SOAP with certificates.

8. Custom Scripting Adjustments (Groovy/JavaScript)

Some scripts refer to Neo-specific:

  • Endpoints
  • Log files
  • Environment variables
  • Adapter classes
  • Tenant metadata

These must be refactored to support CF equivalents.

9. Monitoring Experience Differences

Neo

  • Heavy reliance on Neo cockpit
  • Simplified logging UI
  • Access logs separate from application logs

CF

  • CPI Monitor in Integration Suite
  • Centralized message processing logs
  • Audit logging via SAP Audit Log Service
  • Better integrations with external monitoring tools

Impact:
Monitoring dashboards and alerting need reconfiguration.

Conclusion

Migrating SAP Cloud Integration from Neo to Cloud Foundry is a strategic, time-sensitive initiative as Neo retires in 2028. However, the migration is not a technical copy-paste.
Neo and Cloud Foundry differ significantly in:

  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & audit mechanisms
  • Environment variables
  • OAuth & API access
  • Transport landscape
  • Runtime services
  • Security configuration

By understanding these environment-specific differences early - and adjusting integration flows, scripts, endpoints, and credentials accordingly - you can avoid migration failures, reduce manual fixes, and ensure a smooth transition to the SAP Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry.

If planned well, the Cloud Foundry environment offers:

  • Better scalability
  • CI/CD readiness
  • Modern logging and monitoring
  • Hyperscaler flexibility
  • Improved integration lifecycle governance

The best time to start preparing is now.

entry.content:
Dear @Matt42,

That popup is the generic SAPUI5 Runtime Adaptation (Adapt UI) draft activation failed message it’s not specific to your custom field. SAP even has a Note for exactly this symptom which usually means the backend repository save/activate failed

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003431777

Also step to check

1. Verify the custom field is really ready for this app

In Custom Fields app:

  • Field Status = Published
  • Business Context matches what the app can extend. For Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document (F0843) the extensibility help points to Material Document Item as the relevant area

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/df404e3e691f44eabd3fa2ee0412010d.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F0843')/S35

2. Discard the adaptation draft

In the Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document app:

  • Adapt UI
  • Go to Drafts/Versioning and Discard Draft
  • Close the app completely, reopen then re-do the change and activate again

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4fc8d03390c342da8a60f8ee387bca1a/b9de62a11b7941a08c549e0d4e196839.html

3. Make sure you’re adapting in the correct tenant in Public Cloud

In public edition, key-user extensions are expected to be created/collected in the customizing tenant of the DEV system, then moved via Export Software Collection / Import Collection
If you’re trying to activate in a tenant where key-user changes/transports are restricted activation may fail with this generic message.

4. If it still fails, capture the real error and raise an incydent to SAP

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: BOm component Validation
entry.content: I_RC29P-STLAL is always initial in PCSD0005 because SAP doesn’t fill it at that stage. Use RC29K-STLAL (global BOM header structure) or read from MAST/STKO to get the correct alternative BOM. This way, your validation will only compare components within the same alternative BOM, avoiding false duplicate errors across different alternatives.

entry.title: Re: Clarification Needed on Revised Cost Appearing Higher...
entry.content:
Good day @rohini_dutta21 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f369b2eff700401494ba6e7c9a573288/e744f2b8eb23465fa93e058faed4aa99.html

Answer to question 1: The Revised Cost can become higher than the PO value when actual, accruals or estimated deviation are factored into the cost.

Answer to question 2: Yes, this behaviour is considered standard and it is linked to cost monitoring logic. SAP adjusts the value dynamically as more information becomes available.

Answer to question 3: For accuracy and to ensure alignment between Revised Cost and PO amounts, I recommend you regularly reconcile POs, invoices and actual costs, monitor your projects or cost centers (Actual/Plan/Commitment). Also review your Accrual Management Settings if you have enabled it and align GR/IR clearing and invoice timing.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: HRBP Value Not Nullified by SF User Connector Despite Blank Input
entry.content:
Hi, In LMS we have a HRBP field. The user previously had a value there, but now in BizX the HRBP field is blank, and the SF User connector file also sends it as blank.

However, in LMS the old HRBP value is still showing , it is not being overwritten or removed when the connector runs.

I tested both approaches, but neither worked:

1.Added: sfuser.connector.updateOnNull=HRBP
Connector runs , but the old HRBP value remains.

2.Added: sfuser.field.transform.data.HRBP.@NULLIFY@=NO_HRBP
I then updated the connector file to send the value "NO_HRBP" for the HR_CONTACT field, and re-ran the SF User Connector.
However, the HRBP value in LMS still did not clear.

My current configuration includes:

sfuser.field.mapping.data.HRBP=HR_CONTACT
sfuser.connector.updateOnNull=HRBP

Is this the expected behavior of the SF User Connector with respect to blank values?
If not, what additional configuration is required to ensure that a blank value from the source correctly nullifies the existing HRBP value in LMS?

entry.title: EDLI Amount Exceeding ₹75 During Arrear Payroll Calculation
entry.content:
Dear Support team,

We are facing an issue with EDLI calculation during arrear payroll processing. As per statutory requirements, the EDLI contribution must not exceed ₹75, irrespective of whether the calculation is for current month, retro payroll, or non-retro arrears.

However, in our current system behavior:

  • EDLI is correctly capped at ₹75 in the current payroll period.

  • But when arrears are processed, the EDLI amount from arrears payroll is added on top of the current period EDLI.

  • This results in a total EDLI amount exceeding ₹75, which is not compliant.

Example:

  • Current month EDLI = ₹75

  • Arrear EDLI = ₹X (system adds this to current period)

  • Total EDLI > ₹75, which is incorrect.

Expected Behavior:

EDLI must be capped at ₹75 total, regardless of retro or non-retro arrears.
The system should not allow EDLI to exceed ₹75 under any scenario.

Please investigate the EDLI calculation logic in arrear payroll. You can check case trough Variant - MR_EDLI_01 under tcode - PC00_M40_CALC.

Thanks & Regards

Mrityunjoy

entry.title: Re: Screen Personas 3.0 MOB GUI - Flavor does not load in...
entry.content:
Hi Jonas,

I had the same Issue.

The reason is because your SAP Version is under 2023's version and there is a bug with the cache loading correctly.

The workaround ist to load a "dummyscipt" like :

session.findById("wnd[0]/usr").tooltip="";
on every refresh of a page. You can simply drag & drop that script you created onto the flavour event OnAfterRefresh.
It will load on every page and cache problem is solved.

entry.title: Re: Jon information table not available for reporting in...
entry.content:
Hi @karthika_sumangla ,

Please check if below information can help you.

This is a common issue when working with standard content embedded stories in SuccessFactors Report Center. The Job Information object not appearing in the Available Objects section typically indicates missing permissions or incomplete schema synchronization.

The issue occurs due to two primary reasons:

  • Missing Role-Based Permissions for Job Information data access
  • Incomplete schema synchronization after story enablement

Below are the suggestion for some troubleshooting steps related with your issue:

Step 1:

Verify Role-Based Permissions
For Employee Central data like Job Information, users must have specific permissions:

  • Navigate to Manage Permission Roles
  • Open the role assigned to the affected user
  • Ensure the following permissions are granted:
    • Job Information Actions: Both "View Current" and "View History" permissions
    • Employment Details MSS (if using employment-related fields)
    • Personal Information Actions: "View Current" and "View History" (if using personal info fields) 

Step 2:

Check MDF Foundation Objects Permissions
If the issue persists, verify Foundation Object permissions:

  1. Go to Manage Permission Roles
  2. Open the relevant role
  3. Navigate to MDF Foundation Objects
  4. Under Field Level Overrides, ensure Start Date is not set to "No Access" ,
  5. Remove or change any "No Access" overrides for the Start Date field

Step 3:

Run Schema Synchronization Jobs
Execute the following jobs in Provisioning in this specific order:

  • Clear MDF Cache:
    • Go to Provisioning → affected company
      Search for "Clear cache" under MDF Cache Tool
      Run the cache clearing job
  • MDF Object Definition To DB SYNC:
    • Run this job from Provisioning
      Alternatively, run from Admin Center → Scheduled Job Manager (if previously created) 
  • Save Changes To Report Configuration Object Job:
    • Create and run this job after the MDF sync completes
      Ensure "Custom Schema" checkbox is selected
      Wait for completion before proceeding

Step 4:

Verify Schema Availability
After running the synchronization jobs:

  1. Log into the BizX environment
  2. Check if the Job Information object now appears in Available Objects
  3. Test the story report to confirm data is displaying correctly

Additional Troubleshooting
If the issue persists after following these steps:

  1. Check Configure Object Definitions for any trailing spaces in object names 
  2. Verify that the "Create Story" permission is enabled for the user 
  3. Consider opening a support ticket for backend schema reload if needed 

The order of job execution is critical - the MDF Object Definition sync must complete successfully before running the Save Changes job.

References for this answer:
https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-q-a/urgent-help-required-lms-data-in-story-reports/qaq-p/12733177

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/story-type-not-showing-as-an-option-on-report-centre/qaq-p/12819816

https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/story-reports/permissions-required-for-using-story-reports

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-q-a/is-job-information-history-permission-necessary-for-seamless-running-of/qaq-p/13968895

3003716 - Cannot create new Story query - list of schemas not loading and error "Sorry, the server did not send the data you need" is displayed

3042974 - Schemas missing in Story

Best Regards.
Thiago Eva

entry.title: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud ERP: Quality Inspection with Serial Numbers using Warehouse Management
entry.content:
Quality Inspection with Serial Numbers using Warehouse Management (WM)

Introduction

This blog demonstrates how to integrate Quality Inspection with serial number handling in SAP Warehouse Management (WM). Performing Quality Inspection on serial number–managed materials within WM can be challenging because serial numbers are not automatically transferred to the inspection lot (Origin 17). This article provides guidance on leveraging configuration settings and alternative applications to streamline processes for serialized products in a WM environment.

Business Scenario

Organizations often require serial number tracking during goods receipt and quality inspection to ensure traceability and compliance. In this scenario the serialized stock is handled using warehouse management. 

Required Configuration

  • Serial number profile must be maintained correctly.  Customizing: Define Serial Number Profiles, using SSCUI ID – 103636, activate the WM settings for the serial number profile.
  • The serial number profile must contain the following procedures
    • QMSL for results recording
    • MMSL for Stock Postings in the Context of Usage Decisions

  • And the WM serialization setting must be activated

Master Data

  • Activate QM in procurement for material. The 'Serial Number Possible' checkbox should be selected for the inspection type. 
  •  

     

  • Assign serial number profile in material master on the Work Scheduling tab page, there is a corresponding serial number field. Serial number profile can be assigned in other views as well. E.g Purchasing. 

 

Step-by-Step Process

  • Post Goods Receipt using app ‘Post Goods Movement’ - MIGO and capture serial numbers.

  •  System creates an inspection lot automatically.

  • It can be noticed that the serial numbers are not visible in the created Inspection lot.

  • To assign serial numbers, perform inspection using app Record Inspection Results or Record Inspection Results Hierarchical  Worklist - > Edit -> Serial Number for Lot (QE01/QE51 ).
  • Fiori app can be used only after assignment of Serial Numbers in QE01

.

(If serial numbers are automatically assigned we can directly navigate to "Unit to be inspected")

  • Simply click on "Unit to be Inspected" -> Enter or assign serial number or copy from reference document.

 

 

  • Serial numbers are transferred to the inspection lot, you can see in the Fiori apps and  QE* t-codes. 

  • Results can be recorded for serial numbers.  

Conclusion

With proper configuration and the right applications, QM inspection for serialized products in a WM environment can be carried out seamlessly, ensuring precise quality checks and optimized warehouse operations.


SAP Help documentation:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d1e58be39d884a0dbf75a7526a9acbf4/2573ceec2b414c508d0e02a2a3ad1ee4.html?q=serial+number

 

 

🔎Find All of Our Assets

SAP S/4HANA Cloud is the foundation of the intelligent, sustainable enterprise and is an innovative, robust, and scalable ERP. We at Cloud ERP Product Success and Cloud Co-Innovation offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

✔️ On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

❓ On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is another new a classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research “Agents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI” says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI’s massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: “In one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated” said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added “There are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine… perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? 🙃

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: Bootstrapping SAP Commerce Cloud Projects with ccv2-project-template
entry.content:
Introduction

Starting a new SAP Commerce Cloud (CCv2) project often involves a lot of setup overhead: configuring the platform, creating required modules (storefront, accelerator or custom extensions), setting up dependencies, database, hotfolders/cloud integration, and ensuring the project follows best practices. That’s where ccv2-project-template comes in: a starter template that gives you a working, best-practice project layout — with backend, storefront, build scripts and local dev setup — out of the box.

Markus Perndorfer, an SAP Commerce expert and community contributor, created the ccv2-project-template — a starter template that gives you a clean, production-ready project skeleton for SAP Commerce Cloud.

GitHub: https://github.com/sap-commerce-tools/ccv2-project-template

In this blog, we’ll walk through:

  • What ccv2-project-template offers — its structure and components
  • Why using a template matters (benefits)
  • A step-by-step guide to use it to spin up your own CCv2 project
  • Some customization tips (especially useful for B2B / B2C / Spartacus setups)
  • Pitfalls / what to watch out for

What Is ccv2-project-template — At a Glance

The ccv2-project-template is a GitHub starter template for CCv2. It provides:

  • A ready-made CCv2 project structure
  • Gradle-based build using the Commerce Gradle plugin
  • core-customize folder with clean extension groupings
  • Storefront setup under js-storefront
  • Docker-based local environment (DB + hotfolder simulation)
  • Manifest-based 
  • Standardized B2C/B2B-compatible layout

Why Use a Template — Key Benefits

Using ccv2-project-template gives several advantages vs. “rolling everything yourself”:

  • Faster time to first compile/run: You don’t spend weeks manually wiring platform, extensions, storefront, DB, etc.
  • Consistency and Best Practices baked in: Since the template reflects a best-practice layout, team-to-team variability reduces; easier onboarding for developers.
  • Simpler local development: Docker + automated scripts make it easy for any dev to spin up working local instance.
  • Easier upgrades / maintenance: Starting with a standard baseline means future upgrades (patches, version bumps) are easier — fewer custom hacks/spaghetti configurations.
  • Better separation of concerns: frontend vs backend vs config vs data — neatly separated, making architecture cleaner (and compatible with CI/CD, modular builds).
  • Standard storefront integration: If you plan to use a modern JS-based storefront (Spartacus / headless / composable), the template already gives structure.
  • Given that many teams using CCv2 may have tight deadlines (especially in B2C setups), this template significantly reduces “ramp-up” overhead.

Step-by-Step: Set Up a New CCv2 Project Using ccv2-project-template:

1. Clone / Fork the template repo

git clone https://github.com/sap-commerce-tools/ccv2-project-template.git my-commerce-project  
cd my-commerce-project

You can also fork if you plan to maintain your customizations separately.

2. Explore the structure:

  • core-customize/ → your core and custom extensions
  • js-storefront/ → JS storefront 
  • docker-resources/ → DB + Azurite
  • manifest.json → platform bootstrap configuration

3. Ensure you have prerequisites

  • Java & Gradle (Gradle wrapper is included / configured; the build script uses Gradle). 
  • Database system (or you can rely on the dockerized DB setup as provided)
  • If using cloud-hotfolder simulation: make sure Docker / Azurite (or equivalent storage emulator) works on your machine.

4. Use Gradle + sap.commerce.build.ccv2 plugin to bootstrap

In core-customize/build.gradle.kts, you will see the build configured with sap.commerce.build and sap.commerce.build.ccv2 plugins. 

Basic commands to run:

CommandPurpose
./gradlew bootstrapPlatformUnpacks SAP Commerce platform + necessary extensions based on manifest.json
./gradlew installManifestAddonsInstall the addons/extensions defined in manifest.
./gradlew yclean yall(or equivalent)Build & compile all extensions (similar to ant clean all) — i.e. full build.
./gradlew setupLocalDevelopment A custom task defined by the template that orchestrates bootstrap + DB + hotfolder + addons + dev properties — basically gets local dev ready. 

5. Commit / Version Control & Team Onboarding

Because the template gives a clean, well-structured layout, it's easier to commit to Git (or your project's repo), onboard other developers, and maintain standards. Over time, your custom modules/extensions can evolve, but the scaffold remains clean.

Customizing the Template — What to Do for Real-World Projects

The ccv2-project-template is a starting point — but real projects often have specific requirements (B2B, custom extensions, integrations, multiple storefronts).

Here are some tips for customising:

  • Update the manifest.json: Add / remove platform extensions or addons as per your project needs (e.g. custom B2B modules, custom integrations, payment providers). The Gradle plugin supports manifest-based configuration. 
  • Add custom extensions in localextensions.xml: Instead of messy manual extension additions, create your own modules inside core-customize/hybris/custom, making sure they follow the standard extension packaging and build structure.
  • Front-end / storefront flexibility: Replace or extend the js-storefront with your own storefront (headless, custom UI) — since structure is modular, backend doesn’t get tangled.
  • CI / CD integration: Once local dev works, configure pipelines for builds/deploys using this structure (especially helpful for teams working with DevOps / automated deployments).
  • Database / data handling: If you use non-MS SQL DB or need custom data loads (impex, sample data, seeds), augment the setup — but the base scaffolding helps consistency.
  • Environment Configurations: Use different property files / environment-specific configs to isolate dev / QA / prod setups.

What to Watch Out / Potential Pitfalls

While ccv2-project-template is powerful, few caveats:

  • Platform version upgrade: The template is currently based on SAP Commerce 2211. If you plan to upgrade to future versions, ensure compatibility (extensions, manifest, build scripts). 
  • Dependencies / Licenses not automatically resolved: You may need to manually supply SAP Commerce platform zip or dependencies (especially if license-based).
  • Docker resource constraints: Running full SAP Commerce + DB + hotfolder + storefront locally via Docker may be resource heavy (memory, CPU) — ensure your dev machine has enough capacity.
  • Learning curve for Gradle-based build vs traditional Ant/HAC builds: For developers used to older Hybris/Commerce setups, adjusting to Gradle + manifest + modular setup needs some ramp-up.

About the Creator — Markus Perndorfer

Before getting to conclusion, it’s important to recognise the effort behind this template.

Markus Perndorfer has been a long-time SAP Commerce Consultant, Architect, and community builder. Over the years, he has published open-source tools, accelerators, patterns, and best-practice guides that simplify life for Commerce developers.

This template reflects his deep project experience and solves many of the real-world pain points teams face when starting CCv2 implementations.

Conclusion

For anyone working with SAP Commerce Cloud (CCv2), particularly teams building new projects or modernizing existing ones, ccv2-project-template is an excellent foundation. It removes a lot of boilerplate, enforces best practices, and enables faster time-to-development — letting you focus on business logic, features, and integrations rather than setup overhead.

 

SAP Commerce Cloud SAP Commerce

entry.title: Re: 采购信息记录阶梯价如何维护？
entry.content:
Dear @jayden_glamour,

How to maintain scale prices for a Purchasing Info Record in Public Cloud

  • In Manage Purchasing Info Records (F1982) you can maintain only the Gross Price condition in info records, so it’s not the right place for broader condition maintenance
  • To maintain price scales, SAP recommended way is:
    1. Open Change Purchasing Info Record app
    2. Open the PIR
    3. Choose Conditions
    4. Maintain the scale lines and Save

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2911340

Mass maintenance PIRs

  • Use Mass Changes to Purchasing Info Records in Offline (Excel)
  • Be careful with Online mass changes if PIR pricing conditions contain scale lines, applying mass changes can remove the scale lines. SAP explicitly warns about this

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3189536

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/4a2e6dc6c3fd401dad81ec595c6a90db.html

How to add a new pricing condition type in CBC:

  1. Define Condition Types - Set Pricing Condition Types – Purchasing (101094)
    • Create/copy a condition type
    • Maintain control data

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3663614

  1. Set Calculation Schema – Purchasing (101095)
    • Insert your new condition type into the relevant purchasing calculation schema pricing procedure, set sequence/statistical/subtotals as needed

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3043325

If you want scales on that new condition type, ensure the condition type is configured to support scales

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3417918

In Public Cloud you cannot change SAP standard delivered objects, so you typically need the full custom flow approach Z copies of procedure + Z price condition + Z supplementary procedure then determine the new procedure described step by step in SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002844597

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAC - Requesting Help: Displaying Lock Status for Input-Ready Query Based Planning Model
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm working with an SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Story that is connected to a planning model sourced from a BEx input-ready query.

My goal is to display a clear message to the user in the Story when the currently selected planning perimeter (based on filter context) is locked by another user. This should happen immediately upon opening the Story.

What I've Tried

  1. Table_Data.getPlanning().isEnabled():

    • I attempted to use this method within the onInitialization script of the Story/Application.

    • Result: This function does not seem to reflect the lock status of the selected perimeter. It returns true/false based on general table editability, not the current external lock status, making it unhelpful for this specific scenario.

  2. Cell Coloring (Workaround Observation):

    • I observed that when a table is configured for planning, I can set a specific formatting for editable cells (coloring for instance) which is correctly suppressed when the table cannot be edited because of an external lock on the same selection. This is excellent, as it proves the lock status is being communicated to the SAC client.

    • How can I programmatically determine if the table's cells are currently editable/colored (unlocked) or non-editable/not-colored (locked) without requiring the user to make a selection in a cell of the table (assuming that javascript can tell me the coloring of a cell)? Ex.  If I can detect the non-editable coloring/state (i.e., the lock is active), I will display my custom "Perimeter is Locked" message. Otherwise (if the table is editable), I will assume the perimeter is free.

Is there any SAC API method (e.g., in Table, PlanningModel, or getPlanning()) that exposes the lock status of a table based on a Bex input ready query?

Any advice or alternative approaches would be greatly appreciated!

Regards,

Hendel

entry.title: Re: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Hi @gizemsoylutr ,

Thank you for sharing the details. 

I've built a similar CTI widget, but with a different tech stack (Tailwind-CSS-based frontend and a Node.js backend). The widget can simulate incoming call and integrates with NICE CXone via their APIs.

However, during testing I encountered a behaviour that I'm not fully sure about, and I wanted to check whether this scenario works correctly in your widget setup as well.

Issue Observed

After Accepting the call, SAP Service Cloud automatically opens the Agent Desktop and the customer gets auto-confirmed (as expected).

But if, during the active call, you navigate to another screen (Contract account, Case, Customer, etc) and then try to END the call from this new screen, the END action fails-the call continues to run.

My hypothesis is that since the screen context is changes, the window.postMessage or window.parent.postMessage channel breaks, causing the CTI widget instance on the new screen to lose connection to the original call context--and therefore the END message never reaches the Service Cloud.

Question

Have you tested this scenario in your widget implementation? Does END work even after navigating away from the Agent Desktop screen?

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Hi I need Section weight available in the worksheet how to do it
entry.content: There are a couple of ways to do this using custom fields. If the section weights are standard for everyone, you can just put a custom field in entry level using a hard coded value. For example, if the business goals section has a section weight of 35% for everyone, just create a custom percent field that is set to 35%. If there is variation, you might be able to use a lookup table that mimics the parameters of the bonus plans to derive a correct % for each user. The other option would be to use a ALCF that equals the section weight and then aggregates to the entry level. If you have multiple assignments, you would create a field =1 as a counter and then another field for the section weight. Then you aggregate both and create another entry level field to do the calculation like section (weight 1 + section weight 2)/(counter 1 + counter 2), which would yield something like (30+40)/(1+1) to display 35.

entry.title: Re: MDG Materials Duplicate Check
entry.content:
Dear @stefan_bogesch 
The reason why the Duplicate Check Pops Up Without Real Duplicates due to following reasons. Fuzzy Matching Logic, SAP MDG uses Data Quality Management (DQM) or generic duplicate check methods that rely on similarity scores. If two descriptions are “close enough” (e.g., Pump Motor vs. Pump-Motor), the system flags them. Normalization Rules, the duplicate check often strips out spaces, hyphens, or capitalization. For example, Steel Rod and STEELROD may be treated as duplicates.

Indexing Delays or Cache Effects also. Sometimes the search index isn’t fully updated, so older entries or partial matches cause false positives.

Threshold Settings for the duplicate check has configurable thresholds for similarity. If the threshold is set too low, even minor overlaps trigger the popup.

Search Provider Behavior, Depending on whether you use Enterprise Search or HANA Search, the matching logic differs. Enterprise Search tends to be broader, while HANA Search can be tuned more precisely.

The best practice is to combine Material Description with other attributes (like Material Type or Group) for duplicate checks. Regularly cleanse material master data to avoid near-duplicates that confuse the algorithm. Document your match profiles and thresholds so the team understands why certain cases trigger warnings.

entry.title: Re: Guidance on Global Settlement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud PS
entry.content:
Hello @BlasRosello4 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/9be4cd51f30df73ae10000000a44176d.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2508.500

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/894dbc43f6d34a7aaf23d5fed6794aad.html?locale=en-US

In summary, the root cause why you are seeing that error is because you seem to be trying to settle origin 300 costs (AuC) again from the WBS, which the public cloud, due to its clean-core principle does not allow.

The correct approach/standard step is to settle from the AuC to the final asset and not directly from the WBS. Make sure you use the Transfer Asset function or settlement from AuC to finalise your capitalisation.

I have listed the steps to guid your process flow to ensure successful settlement:

Step 1: In your initial setup, create project, assign investment Profile to WBS. The enables the system to generate AuC asset and settlement rule.

Step 2: Post Costs to WBS. Direct postings for example service, goods and time go to the WBS

Step 3: Run settlement (WBS --> AuC) by using Execute Settlement-Projects app to ensure settlement rule is active and costs move to origin 300

Step 4: Use Managed Fixed Assets app to create the final capitalised asset

Step 5: Use the Transfer Asset (Managed Fixd Assets) app to transfer AuC to Final Asset

This will ensure that origin 300 costs are settled from AuC and not from WBS.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to make z fields mandatory in ME21N(header level)...
entry.content:
Dear @MukhammadAziz 

The Z‑fields at the header level of ME21N (Purchase Order creation), but even though the ABAPer marked them as “required,” the PO can still be saved without values. That’s a common issue because simply setting the screen field as required in the screen painter or PBO logic doesn’t enforce the check at save/commit level.

Use BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST (Recommended)
This BAdI is specifically designed for custom validations in PO processing. Implement method PROCESS_HEADER or CHECK Read your Z‑fields from the header. If they are initial (empty), raise an error message (MESSAGE e...) so the PO cannot be saved. This ensures the system blocks SAVE until the fields are filled.

You can work with User Exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_012 (Include ZXM06U43)
This exit is triggered during PO checks. You can add similar validation logic here. Works, but less flexible and not as clean as the BAdI.

Hope above solutions will help you
